Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine - we have visual contact with remains of the Italian group.
I don't see them.
Eh, bien. *I* have visual contact. They're at about eleven o'clock and burning all their fuel to get to Tripoli.
Right. Safe to assume they're being followed?
I think it's safe to assume that they've been fired upon within the last hour. I think one of them is still on fire.
Right. Let's see if we can put ourselves between them and anybody who's following them. These people deserve a chance to catch their breath.
Oui, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
You've talked to the Italians, Capitaine? What did you learn? What happened at Suez?
Nothing good. The Italians and the Brits made their rendezvous on schedule, but attracted an unspecified number of Morgana subs along the way.
They took some damage, got slowed down, and that gave a bunch of Vanities just enough time to make a "grand procession" through the Red Sea.
On top of everything else, a few Morgana groups that had been nestled in the Aegean came out to feed. It was a pretty thorough disaster.
And what are we doing about it?

Fields.MenuText: Word of the disaster is making its way up to the big brass. They may have some ideas.
I'm pretty sure the French would want you to fall back to Tunisia and play defense.
I'd like to go on the offensive, but we need more information.

Fields.DialogueText: That doesn't solve the problem, though.
Formidable! Maybe they'll form a committee!
... My best guess is that we've got a cloud of hungry, damaged Morganas pillaging everything they can grab from maybe Alexandria to Beirut. If we're lucky, some are turning on each other.
What we need now is all hands on deck. Soviet Black Sea assets, whatever the Turks can spare, reinforcements from Britain and Italy-
So where do we start?
I'll let you know when I figure it out.
You've finished your letters, Capitaine?
I don't actually know if they're worth sending. Some of what I'm proposing here crosses lines that people won't want me to cross.
For now.
In the meantime, what do we do now? Stay at Tripoli and try to keep the Morganes from pushing farther west?
No. Unless somebody gives me a strong argument to the contrary, I think we head east.
The damage the Morganas are doing around the Levant will be attracting other Morganas from around the Mediterranean and the Red Sea.
We need to see how bad it is, and how hard it's going to be to get Suez back under some kind of control.
D'accord. But you should probably know that Tripoli can still use our help today.
Something's coming?
Oui.
Right. I'll meet you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
Do you think it's right? What you're proposing?
Yes.
Bon. Then it's worth sending. I'm not naive - I know that French military history is full of good ideas ignored by small men - but all you can do is be honest and have faith you'll be heard.

Fields.MenuText: That's my thinking.
"Have faith" is a little strong. I'm aiming for "maintain a shred of hope."
I usually prefer to find a way to get my thumb on the scale.

Fields.DialogueText: That's why you're better at your job than I would be.
Then you've officially spent too long writing these letters.
I could take a look at them before you post them, si tu veux. If another set of eyes might make you feel any better.
"Tu?"
Hm?
I think that's the first time you've ever used the informal "you" with me. I like it.
Then it's the new normal.
I'm afraid your reward is getting to review a stack of military correspondence, though. Thank you for the offer.
Ha! You only have to thank me if you like what I have to say.
It's so quiet.
*BOOM*
Merde!
What was that? Are we hit?
Non! That was us getting lucky, Capitaine! A torpedo attack gone wrong - there's a submarine here somewhere!
@BATTLE
Let's not count on getting lucky twice.
I know. I'd like to say it's a nice change, but...
Ç'est juste sinistre.

Fields.MenuText: Exactly.
And "sinister" isn't much of a change at all.
You said it, not me.

Fields.DialogueText: They said at Tripoli that they thought people were leaving the villages along the Libyan coast - they think the mist here has been especially awful since Suez.
We'll fix it, Capitaine. Somehow.
Oh, I read your letters!
What did you think?
I could make the obvious point that I'm a very awkward fit to be the flagship of a massive multinational undertaking involving Muslims, atheists, and the English.

Fields.MenuText: You may be named after a saint, but you're not out there evangelizing for Catholicism.
Yeah, I don't care.
It should help keep the French nationalists from dragging you into propaganda duty.

Fields.DialogueText: Tu as raison. Still, a more culturally neutral battleship might-
Nope.
D'accord. Merci, Capitaine.
... I wouldn't want to do this without you, Jeanne.
I don't care if there are other Belles that might look better on paper. You're the one we need.
Capitaine...
Jeanne?
*snaps fingers* Jeanne?
Oh! Capitaine, pardonnez-moi!
Mm?
Sorry to interrupt. I've got water if you want it - you've been out in the sun for a while.
Have I?

Fields.MenuText: A few hours. If you were human, I'd be worried about sunstroke.
Long enough to prove that Belles can get sunburned.
Maybe? I've been reviewing reports, so what felt like hours might've been ten minutes.

Fields.DialogueText: Mm. Thank you for the water.
Has there been any news?
Not outside of the usual in-house scuttlebutt. The only thing we can get on the radio is Delusion, somewhere off in the distance.
Any good scuttlebutt, then? Are there any grand romances onboard I should know about?

Fields.MenuText: "Grand romances?" I thought you were in it for the smut.
Hey, you're the Belle. You tell me.
I think everybody's happier if I pretend I don't know about my crew's social lives.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine! I'm just a simple, innocent girl trying to learn about the complexities of the great world around her!
Where's the fun in that?
Ah. Tu as raison. Too bad for you.
Drink your water. I think you need it.
The water will help. But, Captaine, Delusion isn't the only Morgane in the area.
Right. Are the new arrivals trying as hard to stay out of our line of fire as she is?
Let me get some aspirin and we'll see...
@BATTLE
You're tempting me to make diagrams. And manuals.
Formidable!
As you command, Capitaine.
... I didn't have a chance to thank you the other day. For being so kind.
About wanting you for a flagship? That wasn't kind. It's probably closer to being selfish.
... Are you all right, by the way? You're still looking a little bit peaked.
Capitaine? I think we're in for some trouble.
You talked to the Belle of that Italian destroyer?
Oui. Their radio systems are dead - she wanted to know what she could expect from Tripoli.
She says things are bad to the east. The Morganes may have some kind of resupply station-
Again?
- at or near southern Crete. And Tobruk is under siege.
She, our Italian friend, thinks that damaged British Belles have taken shelter at Alexandria - they're keeping the mists at bay successfully enough for the city to seem almost normal.
But they can't mount a counter-offensive and the Italians are falling back to west Libya. Not a great long-term strategy.
Did she say anything about unusual weather patterns? If the Morganas have something near Crete that'll be dropping hurricanes on Tobruk...

Fields.MenuText: We should probably assume the worst, then.
Right. We're sure that destroyer wasn't in any shape to help us out?
Sorry. Continue, please.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not so sure. She didn't explicitly mention strange weather. Don't you think she would have?
Her damage was severe, Capitaine. And... even if she wanted to fight, her commanding officer did not.
I'm sorry, Capitaine. I don't have much more to say - though if she'd been caught in an unexpected hurricane, I think she might have mentioned it.
She's Italian, after all. She would have heard about the station we broke in the west.
... Understood.
Okay. Then it sounds like we need to be even more on guard. Let's double the-
Capitaine? They're here.
@BATTLE
It's not clear, Capitaine.
Capitaine? I have a strange favor to ask.
I'm trying to shut out Delusion. She's... very loud today. Très, *très* bruyante.

Fields.MenuText: Okay. Strange favors are the best favors.
Will I have to wear a strange costume?
I'm ready for it.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't think so, but I'd be lying if I said the idea doesn't amuse me.
... Honestly, I'd just like you to talk to me. About almost anything.
You can't just shut her out?
A potential source of information?
If she's hurting you, yeah. It's not like she's overflowing with actionable intelligence anyway - from what you tell me, I don't get the sense other Morganas talk to her much.
She might even volunteer more if you shut her out once in a while - get her off balance.
She's off-balance anyway, Capitaine.
And you sympathize with her?
... I wonder if she's drawn to me for a reason. Sometimes. I wonder if there's some way I can help her.
Mais, oui, I know how crazy that sounds. Can we talk about something else?
You're amazing. You know that?
... Non?
You are. For all the work you put into that stoic, armored facade, I think you care more than just about anyone I've ever met. And you're more generous in spirit.
And you're funny.
And that look on your face when you're trying not to smile, but...
Merde!
... Okay, that wasn't where I was going with my line of thought. Morganas?
Oui, Capitaine.
Right. Remind me to resume complimenting you later.
@BATTLE
... It's almost strange to see a port without any mist at all. If not for all the damaged ships and bombed-out buildings you'd almost think the war was over.
The enemy isn't that far away, Capitaine. Alexandria isn't safe, no matter how it looks.
... You okay? Delusion acting up again?
Non, Capitaine. There's a Fire group buzzing around in the back of my mind. I don't like Fire.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah. Fair enough.
I'm game to get rid of her if you are.
Alexandria doesn't have a happy hirtory with out-of-control flame either.

Fields.DialogueText: Are we ready to head out and intercept?
Oui, Capitaine. More or less. We will be coming back to the port, oui? God willing?
Yeah. With the mist clear, Alexandria has operational airfields. This is our first chance in ages to communicate with the League about the situation here, and I'm not letting it pass by.
But first things first.
@BATTLE
Bienvenue à Alexandrie, Capitaine.
To you, too. I hope the local Belles are being friendly?
Oui. It probably helps that fully half of them have been smitten with you from afar for ages.

Fields.MenuText: Ah, you know I only have eyes for you.
... Which half?
I think you being a hero in your own right is probably a bigger factor.

Fields.DialogueText: Pff! Tais-toi.
Just sketching a kind of map, Capitaine. To help myself remember Alexandria's defenses.
... Unsurprisingly, this is excellent. This is Alexandria's West Harbor?
Oui. You can tell because the East Harbor has more beached Morganes.
Just big steel skeletons. The hulls were stripped off by swarms from other Morganas. It was apparently pretty surreal.

Fields.MenuText: And terrifying.
It's easy to forget that we're fighting the smart ones. Some just go on rampages and burn out.
There's a certain justice to it, I guess.

Fields.DialogueText: What are these things here on your map? Mines?
Oui. Alexandria really needs a lot more.
Yeah, well. Unless they can start producing them in bulk locally, we need to cut down on Morgana traffic before a whole lot of shipping can commence.
Unless the League tells us to shift to protecting Mediterranean convoys, I suppose.

Fields.MenuText: It's possible.
I'd argue against it. We have bigger fish to fry in the near term.
I should note that the usual suspects probably want you back at Marseille.

Fields.DialogueText: Eugh.
But you're not enthused. Neither am I, I suppose.
Specifically?
Well, I think tomorrow - if we haven't had fresh orders or intel from up north - it's time we move on to southern Crete.
You *really* don't like rumors of Morgane infrastructure.
No, I do not.
Jeanne? Still with me?
Ah. Oui. This isn't a... spell, Capitaine. We have a small problem incoming.
Okay. Then let's go resolve it.
@BATTLE
Jeanne, sorry to interrupt. I just... are you drawing?
I've been thinking I should do this sort of thing more often, but-
I'm sure it's hard to find time with Morganas screaming at you and a pesky captain dropping in on you at all hours of the day.
I actually like that last part.
Good. I do too.
May I peek?
Bien sûr!

Fields.MenuText: I'm taking that as confirmation of another Morgana station.
Any chance we sailed into Morgana mist and came out in the North Atlantic? There's some precedent.
I realize I'm making a strong argument for you staying in your quarters here.

Fields.DialogueText: Non, non. It's chilly, but it's not February 1431.
What did they do for warmth in February 1431?
Non, Capitaine. I know where we are.
Oui. It seems likely enough.
Capitaine - the enemy has a guard dog out.
How bad?
Vanity group bad.
So either they're sensible enough to have a heavy guard on their work-in-progress station, or - to drag out your metaphor - the big dog is staying by the food dish.
Either way, we have a hard fight ahead of us, and we need to converse enough ammunition to tear down whatever they've built on the other side.
I... I'll meet you on the bridge!
*sigh*
@BATTLE
Jeanne? I have bread. And cheese. And they're good.
Never let it be said you don't know how to make an entrance, Capitaine.
Now, I'm not just here because I don't think you've eaten today.
Lies! Mensonges! Your strange fixation with my well-being is your only weakness!
No, seriously. I haven't eaten today either, and it's grizzly in the officers' mess without you.
Give me cheese before you try to argue the point.
Only because you ask so nicely.
"Grizzly?"
It's Captain-speak for "I've been missing you."
You saw me on the bridge this afternoon.

Fields.MenuText: I know.
Yeah, well, it's been one of those days.
When I'm not talking to do I'm doing paperwork.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah. Je comprends.
... Is it still snowing?
Yeah. And we ought to be within spitting distance of Crete.
You're not unduly concerned?
Set a lot of fires.
I was hoping you'd say something about huddling together to share body heat.
Ha! If I didn't know better, Capitaine, I'd say you were flirting with me.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, I absolutely am.
Uh...
Not if it makes you uncomfortable.

Fields.DialogueText: Have I been misreading you? The last thing I want is-
Merde!

Fields.MenuText: That's near the top of the don't want list, yes.
What's wrong?

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine? Pardonnez-moi - I'm sorry to bother you.
It's fine, Matelot. I'm just... watching half of Gavdos Island burn, I suppose.
We had to blow up the refueling station, Capitaine.
And refueling stations are full of fuel. Yeah.
Still, it's a mess. We should probably try to move a little bit further east - I want to avoid finding ourselves downwind of those fumes.
The lady of the ship is at prayer, Capitaine?
... That's probably as good a way to put it as any. I'll be trying to get her to eat something in a few minutes if you want me to pass a message along.
Non. I just... is there anything we can do to help her? The crew, I mean.

Fields.MenuText: She's not cracking up, Matelot. She's got a headache and she doesn't like fire. It'll pass.
Short of finding islanders to rescue, probably not.
I think all she needs is space.

Fields.DialogueText: Understood, Capitaine.
It's interesting that you'd ask, though. A month ago I'm not sure anyone would've.
It's been a long month, Capitaine.
Yeah. Fair enough.
*ALARM*
And getting longer.
@BATTLE
Any idea how long until we're back in communication range with Alexandria? We really need to get some kind of League salvage operation out to Gavdos in case there's anything left to grab.
If you believe Delusion, there probably isn't. She claims we're being stalked by an Avarice who wants revenge for ruining her treasure stash.
We blew up a Morgana magpie nest? Now I *really* want that salvage team.
Noted. You should eat, by the way.
... I've been thinking, after Alexandria, my inclination is to go east. Try to get some of the Black Sea Fleet in play, maybe coax some support out of the Turkish government, too.
Hm. If the situation weren't so dire, it would be nice to see the Black Sea again. So many of the memories in my head are of the original Jeanne - these are places *I've* really been to. Moi.
Oh, for God's sake, you can't eat that bread without butter. Here, let me just-

Fields.MenuText: Really? You're buttering my bread?
Don't mind me - I'm just the captain.

Fields.DialogueText: Problem?
Oui.
Okay, I'll just take that bread to go.
@BATTLE
Jeanne? Once again, I come bearing food. Not as fresh as last time, but-
Oh...
Merci, Capitaine, but I'm... intentionally fasting this time.

Fields.MenuText: Don't take this the wrong way, but that sounds like something you should clear with your captain.
Fair enough. As long as you don't take it to extremes.
More food for the commanding officer!

Fields.DialogueText: Mais-
You're not just an officer, Jeanne. You're the ship. If you get light-headed or have any kind of health problems...
I don't mean to keep it going for days, Capitaine. I promise, it won't be an issue.
So... is this prompted by anything in particular?
Like, an idiot captain flirting with you when you weren't interested in flirting and putting you in an uncomfortable position?
Capitaine...
Eugh.
I've never taken vows of celibacy. I wouldn't *want* to take vows of celibacy. I don't want to be... her.
Yeah, you've established that already. But you don't have to have taken vows of celibacy to be bothered by-
I'm not bothered! Can we just talk about something else?
... Okay.

Fields.MenuText: While I talk? Not an attractive look.
You sure you don't mind?
Nah, I can wait.

Fields.DialogueText: You haven't eaten enough today either. And you were planning to eat with me, weren't you?
Go on. I'd feel terrible if you starved yourself unconscious in my cabin.
Well. I really don't want you to feel terrible.
I know.

Fields.MenuText: Jeanne, I don't need that much butter. That's like a mountain.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine? How was your visit to Alexandria? Is there news?
It wasn't much of a visit - just a few hours of meetings close enough to your berth that you probably could have listened in.
Merde. Nobody told me that was an option.
Probably for the best.
To recap: the British are happy with us.
That's just unnatural.
Yeah, yeah. Seriously, we managed to keep the heat off Malta, we wrecked two enemy base-like structures, and we've given Alexandria some breathing room.
And they've agreed they need to bring some Army assets in from the east to keep the pressure on the Morganas in the canal. The last thing anybody wants is for them to do a building project there.
Italy's... I don't know. They're focused on Sicily and Libya - and we've certainly helped with the latter - but I don't think they're being totally forthcoming with how bad their losses were.
And now the Turks and the Soviets are getting extremely concerned that the new Morgana arrivals are going to try to crack the Turkish Straits and make a move on the Black Sea.
And France? My people?
They're probably more worried about the Morganas that are active in the western Mediterranean - and there's still a certain amount of pressure to bring you back for "cultural significance" purposes.
... I want to head for the Aegean, and to the Black Sea if necessary. If it matters, that's what I want. To fight the invaders.

Fields.MenuText: It matters.
Luckily, that's what I want too.
See, now I want to take you to Marseille just to be contrary.

Fields.DialogueText: Merci, Capitaine.
If I admit I was joking, will you stop with the death stare?
It depends on how contrary I'm feeling.
So, right now, this is the plan: we head north to the Aegean and we do what we can to give the Turks, the Italians and the Soviets the freedom to come help us down here.
Meanwhile, in theory, British and Japanese fleets in the Pacific and Indian Oceans will be gathering for a push on the Red Sea from their side.
When the time's right, they try to seal off the Red Sea from the south; we hit Port Said and then push on to the canal from the north.
And hopefully the fact that you'll be the de facto flagship of the Mediterranean side of the operation will make the French government happier with our choices.
Bon. But... there is one complication, Capitaine.
Morganas incoming?
Morganes incoming.
@BATTLE
Tell me you actually had something to eat today.
Enough for this, certainement.
Okay, get to the bridge and get us an intercept course. We're awfully close to Crete again, and the last thing those poor people need is a plague-bearer haunting their coasts.
@BATTLE
Jeanne? I wasn't expecting you to drop by.
... Are you okay?
Oui. Et non. I don't know.
... I feel like I should have brought food.

Fields.MenuText: Next time.
Nah, it's been days since we had anything fresh.
Glad to see you've been paying attention.

Fields.DialogueText: I can-
I'm joking.
What's wrong?
Something's set Delusion off. I can't make any sense of all her shouting, but she's... disturbed.
And I can't sleep. I know it's not fair bothering you when I've been so useless lately, but-
You haven't been useless a day in your life. How can I help? Coffee?
Ah. Coffee would be lovely! Merci!
... Have I ever told you what Delusion believes? What I think she believes, anyway?
Not in detail.
I think it's God - or *a* god - built the world in order to destroy it. And the Morganes were made by devils to destroy the world, because destroying it before God does will actually save it.
The Belles don't have free will, because we were made by God to save the world so it can be destroyed, and the Morganas used to have free will so they were punished by losing their minds.
She wants me to rise up against God and claim my independence, and she also wants me to beg God to forgive her so she can be herself again.
I think. I'm leaving out a lot of symbolism.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds fun.
I don't suppose she'll go away if we tell her God's giving her a break.
We should probably report all that.

Fields.DialogueText: Blah.
You can't live inside her head, you know. I'm sure she wants you to, but you're not doing anybody any good by obsessing over her fixations.
... If I'm worrying about her, I have a reason not to think constantly about kissing you.

Fields.MenuText: Another reason to stop worrying about her.
Okay, that wasn't where I thought this was going.
Yeah, because that would be *awful*.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha!
Capitaine... I don't want to be the original Jeanne. I don't want to be this doomed virgin who has visions and lives half a life and is burned at the stake as a witch and a madwoman.
But what if I'm supposed to? What if that's who the world needs me to be?
... The world needs you to fight. As yourself. That's all. I don't think-
Disease.
... Is she close, or is that just commentary on my argument?
She's close.
*sigh*
At least that should help you shut Delusion out.
Capitaine?
... Jeanne? What time is it?
About two in the morning, Capitaine.
I don't suppose you're here to resume the kissing conversation?
Okay. What can I do for you?
I've just had an unusually short conversation with Delusion, Capitaine. She thinks... I think she's in trouble.

Fields.MenuText: Good.
From what, exactly?
This isn't doing anything to convince me she's not setting a trap.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. But there's a bigger point.
That's the thing, Capitaine.
D'accord. But she's not asking for a rescue.
She says she blames God, and I think she means me in this particular case, but what she seemed to be saying was that other Morganas had decided she was a liability.
That she wasn't going along with the "plan."
... This did all seem unusually organized. The fueling stations, the push on Suez. I mean, we're still fighting crazy stray cats, but it seems like someone was taking a stab at herding them.
And they're aware of us as a problem.
That's the sort of thing that can lead to complications.
I just jinxed us, didn't I?
@BATTLE
Malheureusement, non.
We've had brief contact with the Turkish authorities, Capitaine. Somewhat complicated by the fact that we had to waste hours on codebooks.
Were theirs out of date or ours?
Ours. I had to beg for help from other Belles.

Fields.MenuText: Okay. North Africa is officially too isolated right now.
You weren't begging. You were politely offering the opportunity to help.
Typical.

Fields.DialogueText: So what's the word?
We're likely to get some support from the Soviet Black Sea Fleet - though it's not official until it comes from them.
And the Turks are hoping for cover while their minelayers do what they can to make the Bosphorus unwelcoming to uninvited guests.
Right. Sounds like you may not be making a near-term return trip to Constanta.
Quelle dommage. It's a beautiful place!
If we can keep the Morganas from getting any closer to it than, say, Limnos, it's probably for the best.
*sigh* Tu as raison, Capitaine. As usual.
It's a very irritating habit.
@BATTLE
Plus I'm good-looking.
I can think of no safe response to that.
Okay, you're looking a little bit haggard.
Capitaine, I'm based on the story of a 15th century girl soldier. I'm meant to look a little bit haggard.
*sigh* Pardonnez-moi.
Delusion has spent the last two hours shouting about how she'll be forgiven if she kills me and I should be grateful because I'm already dead.

Fields.MenuText: She's a charmer, that one.
But she's still keeping her distance?
Do you still think she's in trouble?

Fields.DialogueText: ... Oui.
Oui. I honestly don't think this particular Delusion would know what to do with herself if I died.
She's in pain.
But I take it you still have the sense that it's not just us and Delusion out here? The Morgana groups converging on the Straits aren't that far away?
Let me just...
At least Delusion's usually quieter when the shooting's going on, right?
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Uh-huh.
And you usually make that look really work. Right now you just seem strained.
If you want to talk about inventories instead...

Fields.DialogueText: This is a weird question, but - how much of that do you think is for the benefit of other Morganas? I mean, if she knows they're listening in.
Hm.
Je ne sais pas, Capitaine. I don't suppose they'd be impressed if that *is* what she's up to.
I hope you don't mind a visit. No food this time, just...
Mm.
Okay, I know that look.
I've always loved your optimism, Capitaine.
Huh?
Hey, there.
I'm... in your quarters.
Yeah. You were in kind of a daze - I thought it was a good idea to get you off the deck.
... Merci.
That glass of water over there is yours if you want it.
Capitaine? I had... kind of a waking dream.
Okay.
Most of it was nonsense, but... I wonder if our mastermind here might be a Calamity.
I can't recall reading too many reports about Calamity incarnations in serious leadership roles. Most of them just sleepwalk through taunt/response cycles and then run full-tilt into our side's guns.
Je sais. And I can't prove it. But Despair sometimes goes on - went on - about "the Night-Grinder," and "the sunrise dog with her collar and tail," and...
I'm totally lost.
Pink hair could be the sunrise theme. She's literally got a collar. She drags around a lorry full of ammunition - that could be a tail.
And she attacked our Delusion. Maybe killed her. I'm sure I saw that and it was real.
... Almost sure.
... Has Delusion actually gone quiet?
Oui. Totally. For the first time since Alexandria.
If she was taken out by her own side, could she have been trying to communicate it to you? Could this have been a message?
Je ne sais pas. Maybe? I don't think she was that strong, but-
And if it could be a message, it could also be a trap.
... Do you trust me, Capitaine?
With my crew's lives.
Capitaine! Corruption! Mon Dieu, I've been blind - she's almost on us!
It's fine. We've survived worse than "almost on us."
@BATTLE
Wait, what? Jeanne-
Jeanne, sit down before you fall down.
... Why are you looking at me like that?
Well, for one thing, I'm trying to figure out if you're in shock.
Non. I'm fine.
Yeah, well - the best possible description of what you just went through was a supernatural vision of the feral monster-child you've been trying to help for weeks getting violently assaulted.
Other options include some kind of psychic-magical-I-don't-know-what attack. So, please, let me just worry about you for a minute.
... Merci, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: You're welcome.
Hang on. I'm not done worrying yet.
How many fingers am I holding up?

Fields.DialogueText: Three. And I don't think that's how shock works, Capitaine.
How do you feel?
My head is clearing. And the water helps.
Headache? Nausea?
Oui, to both. But getting better.
It wasn't a trap. What I saw was true. I know it.
I believe you. But the fact that it really happened doesn't mean that it couldn't also be a diversion or-
Not bad. We've had fairly solid radio contact with the Turks - and the Soviets, for that matter - over the last few hours.
... I wonder if Delusion was interfering with our radio all along.

Fields.MenuText: Sure she was - she was broadcasting non-stop. I assume that was part of the point.

Fields.DialogueText: Eugh. Bien sûr.

Fields.MenuText: You haven't heard any more from her since the last time we talked?

Fields.DialogueText: Non. It's been good for sleeping, at least.
I'm glad. You look better.

Fields.MenuText: Table that question for now - we have bigger problems.

Fields.DialogueText: Que se passe-t-il? What's happening?
You'll have noticed the Sin group we're speeding toward.
It had caught my eye, oui.
That's the first genuinely big piece of our Aegean problem. It's the tail end of a force that's been looting the area around Iznik; they're now finally making their way up to the Turkish Straits.
And this isn't something the minelayers want to deal with. Je comprends.
Up for a big fight?
Capitaine, really. Do you think I carry this sword around just because it looks good?

Fields.MenuText: I would.
I mean, you make it look *really* good.
Point taken.

Fields.DialogueText: @BATTLE
You don't know how much it weighs.
Capitaine? The fire in the mess is out. How are things here?
No flirting on the bridge, Capitaine.
I don't recall agreeing to that.
Capitaine? Vanity group.
I see them.
Vanity group!
We're ready, Jeanne.
I know we're ready. I'm asking for permission to charge.

Fields.MenuText: Oh. Granted.
As long as we're not careless about it.
This would be so much easier if the Black Sea Fleet was in position...

Fields.DialogueText: Merci.
As long as they're ready to move on Egypt when they do come out, it's fine.
@BATTLE
You all right?
Oui. The last fires are almost out.
Yeah, but you were in a mood even before the shooting started.
Capitaine? Mademoiselle? We have preliminary damage reports for you...
The Capitaine was just in the middle of telling me what kind of mood I'm in, Matelot.
... Permission to run away?
Granted.
So what's going on?
Delusion is back. She sounds terrible.

Fields.MenuText: You think she's hurt.
Trap. Trap, trap, trap.
Is she saying anything we need to hear?

Fields.DialogueText: All right. Tell me - is there something I need to know?
She's telling us where to find her, Capitaine.
... Is it far?
If she's luring us away from where we need to be-
Non. Not far.

Fields.MenuText: Okay.
We go carefully.
Right. Let's go see what we're dealing with.

Fields.DialogueText: D'accord.
Oui.
And you want to help her without hurting the war effort, and you don't know how.
I get it. But I don't know how either.
Elle est là.
I see her.
It doesn't look like she can move on her own power.
Non. Calamity - if it was Calamity - left Delusion broken. Look at those wounds.

Fields.MenuText: I don't understand how she's still afloat.
They aren't all from conventional weapons. The other Morganas fed on her?
She called us here to sink her. To finish it.

Fields.DialogueText: Stubbornness?
Peut-être.
Oui. I think you're right.
The first time I talked to her - at the start of all this - I didn't just tell her she wasn't the only one who heard voices.
I told her I would help her if she wanted to be helped. And I think she did. All this time, I really think she kept talking to me because she wanted to be helped.

Fields.MenuText: I'd love to tow her to a port and let engineers take a good look at her - but she's not going to make it that far.
Jeanne, some people can't be helped. If you want to be kind to somebody, be kind to yourself.
You know if you sink her there'll be other Delusions. Other incarnations.

Fields.DialogueText: If you're right about her, maybe she'll remember. Maybe you'll have another chance.
All I want to do is protect people who can't protect themselves, Capitaine. That's the whole point of all of it.

Fields.MenuText: I know.
You also want to travel and map the world. There's more to life than just the shooting.

Fields.DialogueText: Not these days there isn't.
If you want a minute to talk to her before we pull the trigger...
Non. Let's just get this done and see if we can lead a fleet back to Egypt to end this particular disaster.

Fields.MenuText: Deal.
You realize we'll then go back to quietly resisting requests to launch a nationalist propaganda tour, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Bon.
You never know. Maybe there'll be a miracle.
*BOOM*
Capitaine? We've heard from our Soviet and Turkish friends: they're heading south. They should be passing Lesvos within the next couple of hours if they're not harassed along the way.

Fields.MenuText: I would hope so. We were up all night coordinating it.
Heh. How d'you think the original Jeanne would feel about you leading a joint Muslim-atheist fleet?
Good.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, elle serait déconcertée. Baffled... but maybe also pleased?
... Non. Mostly baffled.
It's not our first sleepless night.
Uncomfortably true.
Now we just have to hope that all the other moving parts are coming into place as well.
If they're not, we can just storm the place ourselves. How hard can it be?
... Pretty hard.
Well, we'll get in some practice on the way.
@BATTLE
Ah. Capitaine... I think we need to put those roses away for now.
Incoming?
Oui.
Right. I guess I'm just glad it didn't happen ten minutes sooner.
@BATTLE
Jeanne! To what do I owe the pleasure?
Il n'y a rien de très urgent. I thought I'd ask if you wanted some roses for your quarters, Capitaine.
Roses.
Oui. Roses. Fresh.
Where on earth did you find-
They just... happen around me sometimes.
Okay. That's actually not the strangest thing I've heard this week. Thank you.
Jeanne?
I don't think I've told you that I think I'm falling in love with you.

Fields.MenuText: That does seem like something I would remember.
Well... good.
Don't take this the wrong way, but you look like you're afraid you're about to get hit by lightning.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine, please... don't joke.
Capitaine, please... don't joke.
Capitaine, please... don't joke.
I'm sorry.
I'm not joking. You have to know I feel the same way. Honestly, I've worried I was pressuring you into - you haven't felt pressured, have you?
I'm only joking a little bit, Jeanne. I just... I get the sense you're nervous, and you don't have to be. I mean, you have to know I feel the same way, right?
Honestly, I've worried I was pressuring you into - you haven't felt pressured, have you?
But you have to know I feel the same way. Honestly, I've worried I was pressuring you into - you haven't felt pressured, have you?
Oh, non. *You* I can easily tune out.
... Jeanne, you wild romantic.
Non, I mean, compared to Delusion. And possibly God. And... I'm not making this better, am I?

Fields.MenuText: Probably not.
I still like the way this conversation is going.
I can't really be offended by being called less demanding than Delusion and God.

Fields.DialogueText: Listen... I'm not sure I understand everything you have to worry about. I'm not sure I could.
But a while back you were thinking about whether you were expected to live the same kind of life the original Jeanne did.
More than that. It's... maybe I just have a medieval mindset, Capitaine, but what if I'm being tested? What if there are temptations I need to overcome?

Fields.MenuText: Do you think France would have an English king now if the original Jeanne had had a lover?
We're all being tested, Jeanne. I don't think the two of us getting closer is part of the problem.
I'm not out to pressure you into doing anything you think is wrong.
But I want to give this a try if you do too.
But I will say it doesn't sound like you think this would be wrong. You're just worried about getting punished if you do it.

Fields.DialogueText: Je ne sais pas.
... Non. I don't think so either.
Capitaine...
Well, that's harsh.
But fair?
... Peut-être. I'll have to think about it.
I'm honestly not sure about much of anything, Capitaine. But... there's no point in pretending I don't feel the way I feel. And you deserve to know.
And you should do whatever makes you feel... I don't know. Like the best Jeanne you can be.
Now, I personally hope that involves kissing, but-
Mon Dieu. Look at them all.
The Morganas?
Look at them first - but then look at our side. French, British, Italian, Soviet, all with a common cause.

Fields.MenuText: And all at least a little bit beaten up in the process of getting here.
It's enough to make you think we have a future, isn't it?
I'd be more sentimental if we weren't outnumbered.

Fields.DialogueText: We've done what we can, Capitaine. It's time to stop dwelling on the negative and have a little faith.

Fields.MenuText: ... Is there some personal subtext there?
If you say so. You're more likely to get shot than I am.
In fairness, dwelling on the negative is a big part of my job.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. It is.
Anyway. We've talked to the other captains. We know the plan. There's not much to do now but pick our targets and try to draw the enemy out from around Port Said.
Capitaine? With your permission, I'd like to ask the other Belles to be on the alert for that Calamity group. If there really is a particularly smart one that's coordinating enemy action...

Fields.MenuText: Agreed.
And she victimized one of her own sisters and left her to die alone.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. Delusion was a monster, but that was just... cruel.
Right. Good luck, Jeanne.
Bonne chance, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
We'll talk later.
Right.
I have visual contact with the Soviet line - they're holding!
Any radio news? Is the push from the Red Sea side working?
The only contact I have is very short-range, Capitaine. There was something a few hours ago about a bombardment from land and a host of bombers breaking a Morgana blockade further south...

Fields.MenuText: Further south where?
That would be nice.
Happy rumors are still just rumors.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Not for the first time, I'm damn glad Morganas don't much bother with mines.  Given how long they've controlled the area, they could've set a lot more traps for us.
Je ne sais pas. The Belle telling the story got a high-explosive knock to her conning tower - now she's just singing Vaudeville tunes as she shoots.
Great.
Let's not give them ideas, Capitaine.
Yeah. How are you holding up?
Je ne sais pas. What day is it?
Yeah, I... oh, hey. Jeanne? Look to port.
Does that look like a Morgana group with a Calamity on point?
... Let's blow them up and find out.
@BATTLE
Get the fires out fast, people! I don't think we're going to have the option of withdrawing and licking our wounds this time!
Jeanne, are there any quick patches we need to prioritize? How do the engines sound?
Jeanne, please, stay with me here! There are Morganas on every side - what do we need to work on to-
Capitaine! British and Japanese forces are radioing! They've punched through from the Red Sea!
The Morganes are scattering, Capitaine! Getting rid of the Calamity did it!
... Oh. Okay, then.
If we've got any ammunition left, people, pepper them as they run! Let's encourage them not to try this again!
Capitaine? Un moment!

Oh, hey! Listen, I've talked to the chaplain about services for the people who died fighting at Port Said - and we agreed that there'll also be a few words about... lost souls who need a bit of light.
I don't think it's appropriate to include Delusion with the Morganas' human victims - but I know you think she shouldn't be given up on either, and I respect it.

Fields.MenuText: More or less.
Though I don't recommend making it widely known.
I don't know if that helps you at all...

Fields.DialogueText: Merci, dear Capitaine, but that's not what I want to talk to you about. I've been fasting, and thinking, et... I've had an epiphany.
Okay. What did you have in-
*KISS*
Listen, I'm not saying it has to be perfect, but we need enough working light bulbs in the engine room to know where to walk. Steal them from wherever you can find them.
Oui, Capitaine.
Good. Now, how're you holding up, Matelot? Did you ever hear back from-
Capitaine, no one would ever hold the Maid's kindness against us.
Yeah, I don't know about that.
*GASP*
I've wanted to do that since the day you first set foot on my deck. I really have.

Fields.MenuText: I'm with you.
I think I may need more convincing.
... I think we broke the matelot.

Fields.DialogueText: And I'm done being afraid. Whatever comes from this, whatever price I have to pay, I'll face it proudly... if you're with me.
M... muh...
He'll get over it.
Ah. I think I can be persuasive.
I... don't think this will be easy, Capitaine. Whatever purpose heaven has for me, there are people back home who want the Virgin Reborn.
You'll be resented for corrupting me. Even more than you already have.

Fields.MenuText: I guess I'll have to corrupt you well enough to make it all worthwhile.
Trust me, I've survived worse.
You're worth it.

Fields.DialogueText: *KISS*
Also, we have Morganes incoming. That's why I wanted to do this quickly.
I'll see you on the bridge!
... Right. Bridge. Shooting. Okay.
Buck up, Matelot! We've got work to do.
*whimper*
@BATTLE
Merde! I can't believe I didn't ask her out when I had the chance!
